Graphical abstract The steam reforming of ethanol was studied over supported Ni catalysts. The catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method, using chelating solutions (ethylendiaminetetraacetic acid, EDTA; nitrilotriacetic acid, NTA; and citric acid, CA). The solids were characterised by means of X-ray diffraction, BET specific surface area, temperature programmed reduction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and thermogravimetry analysis. The catalyst prepared from EDTA solution was the most active and selective, with a low amount of carbon deposited after 7 h in reaction. This behaviour was associated with an improvement in the Ni-CeO2 interaction induced by the small NiO particle size obtained from the use of a chelating agent. This sample also showed a high Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio and the smallest particle size of metallic nickel. Keywords Hydrogen production Ni/MgAl2O4-CeO2 Chelating agents Ethanol reforming 1 Introduction Ni catalysts used in ethanol steam reforming reaction are less expensive and have greater availability in comparison to noble metal catalysts. However, their main drawback is the high level of deactivation observed in reaction, due mainly to carbon deposition, sintering and/or inactive phase formation. One strategy for minimising these deactivation phenomena is to control the metallic ensemble. Small particles decrease the carbonaceous deposition rate, since this reaction is sensitive to the structure [1], although small particles are more susceptible to sintering and oxidation. The method used to synthesise the catalyst plays a significant role in controlling the size of the Ni particles [2]. In the literature, the use of aqueous solutions of chelated metal complexes within the wet impregnation method has been reported. This strategy is very interesting, as it maintains the simplicity of the technique; it allows a high level of reproducibility of synthesis, uniform distributions of the active phase and higher metallic dispersions. One characteristic of these solutions is the increase in viscosity during solvent removal in the drying step, inhibiting the distribution of surface species and forming poorly crystallised compounds with high dispersion [3]. Several factors should be considered when using a preparation with chelating ligands, which control the electrostatic interactions between the complex and the support, for instance the pH of the solution and the point of zero charge (PZC) of the support [4,5], the characteristics of the ligand structure, the thermal precursor decomposition, and the drying procedure. The pH of the solution plays a significant role in the formation of the complex compound, in the surface speciation of the support, and in the control of metal-support interactions [6]. The chelating agents most widely used in supported catalysts preparation are ethylendiaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) and citric acid (CA). It is well known that this class of ligands forms soluble and very stable complexes with a wide range of metals. In addition, the obtained precursors contain no elements other than C, H, N or O, thereby avoiding any contamination. The thermal decomposition of the complexes is completed at moderate temperatures, and the residual carbon contamination on the support surface left by the organic part of the precursor is close to that of other methods. Chelating agents have successfully been used in the preparation of hydrodesulphurisation (HDS) catalysts [6–9], for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [10–13] and more recently in catalysts for reforming reactions [14–18]. The group of Yamada have reported the use of organic ligands in preparation of highly active cobalt catalysts for Fischer- Tropsch synthesis. They found an increase of Co dispersion when the NTA chelating agent was employed. The NTA formed Co complexes with a moderate formation constant and a ligand:Co molar ratio equal 1:1. They reported that the presence of chelating agent hindered the sintering of Co during the thermal treatment, due to the bulky structure of the complex and the NTA encapsulation effect with the metal. The [CoL]− complex formed in solution was preserved over the dried catalysts. In addition, they confirmed from a XAFS study that the decrease in particle sizes of Co was due to the interaction of CoOx groups with chelate during calcination [11,11,12,13]. Ortega-Domínguez et al. have studied the effect of chelating agents in the preparation of hydrogenation Ni catalysts. They have also found that the use of EDTA improved the Ni and NiO dispersions, increased the Ni-support interactions and the hydrogenation activity of naphthalene. On the contrary, the catalysts prepared by the addition of CA showed larger particle of Ni (observed by HRTEM) and lower catalytic activity. The molar ratios used in preparation corresponded to the stoichiometric ratios for a complete complexing and the decomposition temperature was low (400 °C). However, the pH of impregnation solutions was missing and probably it could explain the differences observed in particle sizes [19,20]. The role of solution pH in the presence of chelating agents was studied in NiW/γ-Al2O3 HDS catalysts. Santolalla-Vargas et al. have determined that the higher stability of [Ni(CyDTA)]2-complex and an increase of NiWS species were reached at pH = 4 [21]. Bang et al. studied Al2O3-supported Ni catalysts prepared from EDTA solutions in the liquefied natural gas reforming reaction for hydrogen production. They reported smaller metallic Ni particles and a higher Ni dispersion with higher methane adsorption. These authors also found an increase in metal-support interaction due to the Coulombic interaction between positively charged hydroxyl groups of alumina and Ni(EDTA)2− complex. The catalyst prepared with EDTA showed a better catalytic performance and a high sintering resistance during the reforming reaction at 800 °C [17]. Recently, the catalytic performance in methane dry reforming over Ni/SBA-15 catalysts was increased by using chelates. The formation of Ni-O(H)-Si bond assisted by the organic ligand increased the interaction with support and the tolerance to sintering and to carbon deposition. In addition, the electron-pair donor atoms and the high viscosity of chelating solution inhibited the nickel species aggregation and contributed to the formation of Ni particles with size lower than 6 nm [18]. In a previous work, Ni catalysts supported on MgAl2O4 doped by PrO2 or CeO2 were studied in the ethanol steam reforming (ESR) reaction under mild conditions (inlet ethanol concentration = 7.8%, feed molar ratio H2O:C2H5OH = 4.9, reaction temperature = 650 °C, and W/FC2H5OH = 49 g min mol C 2 H 5 OH - 1 ) . The catalyst with CeO2 decomposed under reductive atmosphere showed the best results in ESR [22] with a loss conversion of 6.6% during 10 h in time on stream. The influence of impregnation medium was also studied [23]. The catalyst prepared from an ethanolic solution of Ni(NO3)2 showed a high Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio and an average Ni diameter around 28 nm. The catalytic results in ESR were also promising, although carbon deposition and sintering were observed after 40 h in reaction. In this work with the aim of improving the catalytic performance, Ni catalysts supported over MgAl2O4-CeO2 were prepared using various chelating agents. Their influence on the sizes of Ni particles, the catalytic behaviour under ESR conditions and the deactivation were investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The MgAl2O4 used as support was prepared using the citrate method, under similar experimental conditions described in [22]. The spinel precursor was calcined in two steps: (i) in a N2 flow (180 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 2 h, and (ii) in static air at 700 °C for 1 h. The addition of Ce (CeO2 nominal loading 5 wt.%) was carried out using the wet impregnation method from an aqueous solution of Ce(NO3)3.6H2O (Aldrich, 99%). The modified support was dried at 100 °C in a vacuum for 20 h and was used without calcination. Aqueous solutions of Ni(NO3)2 (Ni nominal loading of 8 wt.%) and a chelating agent (L) of EDTA (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%), NTA (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%) or CA (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.5%) were prepared. The molar ratio of the metal to the ligand was always 1:1. First, the chelating agent was dissolved in a 1 M NH4OH solution to pH 10, to assure its complete solubility and the formation of anionic species. The nitrate aqueous solution was slowly added to the ligand solution, and the pH was maintained by the addition of NH4OH drops. Following this, the complex aqueous solutions were adjusted at a pH (around 6) that was lower than the PZC value of the modified support using an HNO3 solution. They were then aged under stirring at room temperature for 2 h. Then, 1 g of the modified support was added and stirred for 1 h. The solvent was slowly removed under vacuum at 80 °C for 1 h. The dried samples were calcined in static air between room temperature and 650 °C at 10 °C min−1, and then for 3 h at 650 °C. The catalysts are referred to here as NiL. As a reference, a sample without chelating agent was prepared following the same procedure and is designated here as Ninitrate. 2.2 Characterisation of samples The PZC of the support was determined using the salt addition method [24]. The pH of 25 mL KNO3 0.1 M solutions was adjusted using KOH and HNO3 in a pH range between 2 and 12. The pH of each solution (pHinitial) was measured using a pHmeter (Lutron PH-230 SD with a Van London glass electrode). A suspension of 25 mg of powder modified support was formed in each solution under vigorous stirring at 175 rpm for 24 h in an universal stirrer (Edmund Buhler KL-2). Following this, the pH of each suspension was carefully measured (pHend), and ΔpH (estimated as the difference between pHend and pHinitial) plotted as a function of pHinitial. The value of pHinitial at ΔpH = 0 was taken as the PZC. The distinct species present in the impregnation solutions were determined using Medusa software [25]. The equilibrium diagrams were obtained at 25 °C, taking into consideration all the ions present in the solutions. Nickel and cerium chemical compositions were determined by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP) by using a sequential ICP spectrometer Baird ICP 2070 (BEDFORD) with a Czerny Turner monochromator (1 m optical path). The solid samples were brought into solution by an alkali fusion with KHSO4 and subsequent dissolution with an aqueous HCl. Textural properties were recorded using a Micromeritics Gemini V. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and the specific surface areas of samples (SBET) determined by the BET method were obtained from adsorption–desorption measurements of N2 at −196 °C. The samples were previously degassed at 250 °C for 16 h in a N2 flow. Diffraction patterns of samples, XRD, were obtained using a Rigaku D-Max III C diffractometer operated at 30 kV and 20 mA. A radiation CuK α (λ = 0.15418 nm) with an Ni filter and a horizontal goniometer were employed. Step scans were taken over a range of 2θ from 10° to 70° in steps of 3° min−1, and data were collected every 0.05°. Identification of the crystalline phase was made by matching with JCPDS files. The crystallite sizes of NiO and CeO2 were determined using the Scherrer equation. The redox properties of samples were examined using temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) measurements, and the experiments were carried out using a conventional equipment described in [22]. Before the TPR experiments were undertaken, the samples were treated first under an O2 (17%)/He flow (36 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h and then in He flow (30 mL min−1) for 30 min. After cooling in a He flow to room temperature, the samples were reduced in a H2(5 vol.%)/N2 flow (50 mL min −1) from room temperature to 950 °C at 10 °C min―1 and kept at 950 °C for 1 h. The H2 consumption was determined after a previous calibration. X-ray photoelectron analyses (XPS) were performed using a multi-technique system (SPECS). The residual pressure inside the analysis chamber was kept below 2 × 10−8mbar. Ni 2p, Ce 3d and Al 2p spectra were recorded for each fresh sample. All binding energies (BE) were referred to the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV, and the BE for the Al 2p was therefore about 74.1 eV. The samples were ex situ reduced to 650 °C in an H2(5%)/N2 flow for 45 min. In addition, they were treated inside the pre-chamber in a reductive flow of H2(5%)/Ar at 400 °C for 10 min and atmospheric pressure before the XPS measurements were taken, since a reduction at 650 °C could not be carried out in the XPS equipment used in this work. The experimental conditions and data treatment were the same as those described in [26]. The TG-TPO analyses were carried out in a DTG-60 Shimadzu instrument. The samples were heated from room temperature to 1000 °C at 10 °C min−1 under an air flow (50 mL min−1). The carbon amount was expressed as %C and mgC g c a t - 1 h−1. 2.3 Catalytic experiments in ethanol steam reforming The reaction was studied using an experimental setup described elsewhere [27]. In brief, the reactor was operated at 650 °C and atmospheric pressure. The feed to the reactor was a gas mixture of ethanol, water and inert gas. The H2O:C2H5OH molar ratio in the feed was 4.9, and the initial ethanol concentration was around 9.4%. In all experiments, the W/ F C2H5OH was 49 g min m o l C2H5OH - 1 . The amount of catalyst was 50 mg without dilution. Before the catalytic experiments were carried out, the catalyst was in situ reduced in a H2(5%)/N2 flow at 650 °C for 45 min. The reactants and reaction products were analysed online using gas chromatography. The ethanol conversion (XC2H5OH), selectivity to carbon products (Si) and hydrogen yield (YH2) were estimated as described elsewhere [27]. 3 Results and discussion Adequate interaction between the impregnation species and the oxide used as support requires control over the pH of the impregnation solution. Oxides immersed in solutions at pH values below their PZC would adsorb anionic species, whereas at pH values above their PZC, these would adsorb cations [28]. In view of these constraints on the adsorption process involved in catalyst preparation using the impregnation method, the PZC of the support was determined by the “salt addition” method. Fig. 1 presents the curves used to determine the PZC values of the modified support MgAl2O4-CeO2, MgAl2O4 and pure CeO2. The PZC values determined for pure compounds (PZCMgAl2O4 = 9.4 and PZCCeO2 = 7.4) agree with other values in the literature [29,30]. The PZC value of MgAl2O4-CeO2 was 9.6, very close to that of pure spinel; this is reasonable due to the low CeO2 loading. The equilibrium Ni species in the different preparation solutions were obtained from equilibrium diagrams (not shown). The main species in the pH range of the solutions and the equilibrium constants of the complexes formed are summarised in Table 1 . The stability of the complexes could be inferred from the high K values. Hexahydrate nickel [Ni(H2O)6]2+ was the only species in the Ni(NO3)2 aqueous solution at pH = 5.9. In the presence of chelating agents, the main Ni species are anionic. In the case of citric acid, two anionic species, [Ni(CA)2]4− and [Ni(CA)]−, and a cationic species containing an ammonium ligand, [Ni(NH3)]2+, were predicted. The explanation for this is that the CA:Ni molar ratio used in the preparation was lower than that required for the maximum stoichiometry for complexation (CA:Ni = 2). These results indicate that the pH of the impregnating solutions used in preparation was lower than the PZC of the support (Table 1). The average Ni and Ce compositions were 6.2 and 4.7 wt.%, respectively, lower than the nominal ones, Table 2 . The precursor salts used in preparation were in hydrated forms and they would explain the lower values. The adsorption–desorption isotherms of N2 for all the catalysts were of type IV with an H1 hysteresis loop, which is characteristic of mesoporous materials. The specific surface values obtained by the BET method are shown in Table 2. The SBET value of the modified support was 102 m2 g−1. A decrease in SBET from 5% to 22% was observed after impregnation. The X-ray diffraction patterns of the fresh catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . They reveal the presence of MgAl2O4, CeO2 and NiO. The particle sizes of NiO and CeO2 were determined by deconvolution in the 2θ range of interest, using the Scherrer equation. The use of chelating agents in the preparation decreased the particle size of NiO. The dNiO followed the order of 6.2 nm (NiEDTA) < 9.3 nm (NiNTA) < 12.4 nm (NiCA) < 18 nm (Ninitrate), as shown in Table 2. Changes in the CeO2 particle sizes could be also observed. The modified support was used in its dried form, and consequently a surface re-dissolution of CeO2 could occur during the impregnation of complexes with Ni2+, affecting the final dispersion and/or their interaction with Ni. Complementary analyses verified the dissolution of cerium. The impregnation solutions were filtered before the solvent removal and they were analysed by ICP. The results clearly indicated the presence of Ce in the solution. The extent of dissolution was around of 16% in all the samples TPR experiments were carried out to study the metal–support interaction and the influence of the nature of the ligand in the reducibility of Ni and CeO2. The TPR profiles are illustrated in Fig. 3 . All catalysts showed broad TPR profiles with several overlapped peaks. Peaks at low temperature were assigned to the reduction of Ni2+ species weakly interacting with the MgAl2O4; Ni2+ interacting with CeO2 particles; and Ce4+ at the CeO2 surface [31–33]. Peaks I and II at low temperature were observed: at 260 and 338 °C for NiEDTA; 308 and 414 °C for NiNTA; 314 and 497 °C for NiCA; and at 310 and 600 °C for Ninitrate. These differences in reduction temperatures suggest changes in NiO-CeO2 interactions and in Ni reducibility. In addition, this behaviour indicates the presence of species in different environment and needs complementary studies for a correct assignation of species being reduced. The broad peak at high temperature (peak III) was ascribed to the reduction of Ni2+ species interacting more with the support and to the reduction of CeO2 to Ce2O3. The reduction experiments were carried out until 950 °C and bulk CeO2 was also reduced. XRD of samples after TPR (not shown) revealed the presence of Ce2O3. The more intense diffraction peak of CeO2 at 2θ = 28.5° is still observed indicating its partial reduction. The hydrogen consumptions were estimated by the integration of the H2–TPR profile and considering the catalyst composition. They followed the order of Ninitrate (1.11 mol H2/mol Ni) < NiEDTA (1.15) < NiCA (1.22) ≈ NiNTA (1.25). These consumptions were higher than the theoretical ones to the complete reduction of Ni2+ to Ni° in agreement with the surface reduction of Ce4+ and the presence of Ce2O3. In Fig. 4 , XRD patterns are shown for samples reduced under the same conditions as before the reforming runs. In comparison with the XRD of fresh samples, no significant differences were observed except for the presence of Ni0 at 2θ = 51.8°. The peak at 2θ = 43.3° was assigned to NiO. The intensity of this peak was substantially decreased, and its presence implies that the reduction at 650 °C for 45 min was incomplete. This peak was also observed in the XRD of the samples used in the ESR reaction (see below). The particles sizes of Ni and residual NiO were determined using Rietveld refinement over XRD patterns recorded between 2θ = 10°–90° in the step mode (step scan = 0.02°; time step: 5 s). The dNi values followed the order of 2.7 nm (NiEDTA) < 3.7 nm (NiCA) < 4.3 nm (NiNTA) < 4.8 nm (Ninitrate); and dNiO was 4.4 nm (NiEDTA), 12.1 nm (NiCA), 12.6 nm (NiNTA) and 21.1 nm (Ninitrate). A higher Ni dispersion over the reduced NiEDTA could be inferred. The CeO2 particle sizes were preserved after reduction, Table 2. XPS was employed to determine the chemical state and surface composition of Ni and Ce over the reduced samples. The XP spectrum of Ni 2p presented peaks at binding energies corresponding to Ni0 and Ni2+, as shown in Fig. 5 and Table 3 . The presence of Ni2+ indicates that the reduction at 650 °C for 45 min was incomplete; this agrees with the XRD results for the reduced samples (Fig. 4). The additional in situ reduction at 400 °C for 10 min in the pre-chamber was insufficient to complete the NiO reduction. The XP spectrum for Ce 3d exhibited peaks at 880.6–880.9, 881.7–882.0, 884.8–885.0, 886.4–886.0 and 897.8–898.2 eV, corresponding to Ce 3d5/2, and these could be assigned to Ce4+ (v, v´´, v´´´) and Ce3+ (v°, v´) [26] (Fig. 5 and Table 3). The Ni0/Ni surface ratios considered as dispersion measurements are shown in Table 4 . They varied between 0.27 and 0.34, indicating that the dispersion did not change in a meaningful way and is independent of the metallic precursor. These values were unexpected, and could be explained by sintering under reduction conditions, since it is known that smaller particles are easy to sinter. However, the use of chelating agents induced significant changes in the Ce/Ni0 and Ce3+/Ce4+ surface values. These results may be associated with the initial presence of smaller NiO particles in catalysts prepared by the complexing method, improving the Ni-CeO2 interactions and facilitating the CeO2 reduction. The Ce/Ni° surface ratio follows the order NiEDTA > NiNTA > NiCA > Ninitrate. A correlation between the amount of Ce atoms per metallic Ni (Ce/Ni0 ratio by XPS) and NiO particle size, considered as an indirect measure of Ni-CeO2 interaction (the bigger the NiO particle size is, the weaker the interaction), was observed, Fig. 6 . The strong relationship between these two parameters is an evidence of the role of NiO particle size. The bigger NiO particle size is, the lower the amount of Ce atoms per Ni. Differences in Ce3+/Ce4+ values were also determined and were higher for NiEDTA and NiNTA. The presence of the Ce3+- Ce4+ couple increases the carbon resistance [26], since CeO2 can reversibly change its oxidation states, Ce3+- Ce4+, store and release oxygen and mediate in the carbon removal reactions. Catalytic performance of all catalysts at the same reforming conditions is shown in Fig. 7 . A complete initial conversion of ethanol was found for all the catalysts with a H2 yield around 5 mol H2/mol C2H5OH. A slight conversion decay over 7 h in reaction was observed, except for NiEDTA. The main products were H2, CO2, CO and CH4. Except for NiEDTA, C2H4O and C2H4 were also detected in all systems. The selectivities for minority products (CH4, C2H4O and C2H4) over Ninitrate were stable, and were lower than 4%. In the case of NiNTA and NiCA, a slight increase in the C2H4O formation was observed although the H2 yield was almost constant. This behaviour could be attributed to the WGS reaction (CO +H2O ↔ CO2 + H2). From TPR profiles for NiNTA and NiCA could be inferred the presence of Ni species in different environmental which likely were the responsible of this catalytic behaviour. The modified support was also studied under the same reforming conditions and it showed a low reforming capacity. The ethanol conversion decreased from 100% to 66% after 7 h, and simultaneously the selectivity to C2H4O increased from 2 to 47%. The formation of C2 (C2H4+C2H6), C3H6O and CO2 was significant with small amount of H2. As it was expected, these results put in evidence the role of nickel as an active site. In Table 5 , recent results in ESR reaction over Ni catalysts are shown. It must be noted that a direct comparison between results is not possible due to differences in reaction experimental conditions. Reaction temperature, feed composition, residence time, etc. strongly influence the catalytic performance. If the carbon deposition rate is considered as a parameter of stability (see further), the NiEDTA and NiNTA show the best behaviours. However, the performance in ESR reaction on NiEDTA is better since C2H4O and C2 are not observed during 7 h in time on stream. From the catalytic results, no significant deactivation was observed, but the post-reaction characterisation of samples revealed changes that indicate that this phenomenon may appear over a long reaction time. The XRD results for the samples used are shown in Fig. 8 . The MgAl2O4 support was stable under reaction [27], and the Ni0 phase is clearly observed at 2θ = 51.8° in all the samples. A weak peak assigned to NiO is observed in XRD for Ninitrate and NiCA. In comparison with the XRD results for the reduced samples, a degree of sintering could be inferred. The Ni particle sizes after reaction were between 15–20 nm. In addition, a peak at 2θ = 26° assigned to graphitic carbon was detected; its intensity was high for NiCA and Ninitrate and substantially lower for NiNTA and NiEDTA. These differences can be associated with CeO2 dispersion and the high Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio determined for these samples. These results agree with those from TG-TPO analysis for the catalysts used (Fig. 9 ). Weight losses took place between 530 °C and 700 °C due to carbon combustion, and the temperatures at maximum weight loss are shown in Table 6 . The amounts of carbon were lower for NiEDTA and NiNTA, and their low combustion temperatures indicate a lower extent of graphitisation [40]. An analysis of the results shows that NiEDTA gave the best performance in the ethanol steam reforming reaction. This behaviour, as compared with the results for NiNTA, can be assigned to the improvement in Ni-CeO2 interactions (highest Ce/Ni0 value) induced by the low size of NiO particles. 4 Conclusions Ni catalysts supported over MgAl2O4-CeO2 were prepared by wet impregnation, using three different chelating agents, EDTA, NTA and CA, in the impregnation solution. The use of an organic ligand allowed NiO nanoparticles to be obtained with smaller sizes than those obtained in the absence of a chelating agent. A redistribution of CeO2 was also observed. The systems prepared using EDTA and NTA showed smaller NiO and CeO2 particle sizes and the highest Ce3+/Ce4+ values. All catalysts were active in the ethanol steam reforming reaction, with the main products being H2, CO2 and CO. Under the reforming conditions used in this work, the best catalytic performance was obtained over the NiEDTA catalyst. C2H4 and C2H4O were not detected on this catalyst during 7 h of reaction, and the carbon deposition was low. This behaviour was associated with an improvement in the Ni-CeO2 interaction, induced by the small NiO particle size obtained from the use of chelating agent. This sample also showed a high Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio and the smallest particle size of metallic nickel. The use of complex precursors is an interesting strategy for obtaining improved properties for Ni reforming catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The steam reforming of ethanol was studied over supported Ni catalysts. The catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method, using chelating solutions (ethylendiaminetetraacetic acid, EDTA; nitrilotriacetic acid, NTA; and citric acid, CA). The solids were characterised by means of X-ray diffraction, BET specific surface area, temperature programmed reduction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and thermogravimetry analysis. The catalyst prepared from EDTA solution was the most active and selective, with a low amount of carbon deposited after 7 h in reaction. This behaviour was associated with an improvement in the Ni-CeO2 interaction induced by the small NiO particle size obtained from the use of a chelating agent. This sample also showed a high Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio and the smallest particle size of metallic nickel.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogen production from ethanol: Synthesis of Ni catalysts assisted by chelating agents
